feed.title: Combined summary - Removing checkpoints in Bitcoin Core v30

entry.title: Combined summary - Removing checkpoints in Bitcoin Core v30
entry.summary:
The recent deliberations and subsequent decision to remove checkpoints from Bitcoin Core in its version 30 release represent a pivotal shift in the cryptocurrency's development trajectory. Checkpoints were originally implemented as a defensive mechanism against low proof-of-work header spam attacks. However, with the advent of headers pre-sync functionality introduced in Bitcoin Core v24, the necessity for checkpoints has been significantly diminished. This functionality effectively counters the threat posed by such attacks without relying on checkpoints, rendering them redundant.
Further discussions within the Bitcoin development community have highlighted a consensus against the addition of new checkpoints. This stance is primarily driven by the understanding that checkpoints offer limited security benefits in mitigating the risks associated with spam attacks. Additionally, the potential removal of checkpoints raises concerns regarding network stability, particularly the risk of network splits resulting from large-scale reorganizations (reorgs). While scenarios leading to such drastic reorgs are deemed highly improbable, involving speculative situations with aliens or national security agencies, they underscore the network's vulnerability to significant disruptions.
The implications of these reorgs extend beyond technical challenges, touching on existential threats to Bitcoin's value and utility. A catastrophic event that leads to a divergence between current and older versions of Bitcoin Core, along with other implementations that may still enforce checkpoints, could critically undermine the cryptocurrency's integrity. In response to these concerns, there's an ongoing discussion about the formulation of a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP). This proposal aims to establish measures for restoring network consistency post-disruption and advocates for the permanent activation of certain soft fork rules from the genesis block, effectively replacing the need for the last checkpoint header.
This proactive approach towards ensuring Bitcoin's resilience in the face of potential threats underscores a commitment to safeguarding the cryptocurrency's continuity and stability. The proposed changes and the rationale behind the decision-making process can be further explored through the [Bitcoin Core Pull Request](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/0) and additional details on the [Headers Pre-Sync Functionality](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/1), which provide comprehensive insights into the technical underpinnings and future direction of Bitcoin Core development.
